Most of the threads here are concerned with the immediate future of an abortion. For Archie and friends, the 'choice' is an evil one to allow because it is a choice between 'life' and 'death'. However, is this necessarily the case, if we take a longer view?
 
 Consider a couple, Alice and Bob. Alice and Bob are in a committed relationship, they might even be newly married, but at their current point in time neither of them wants children - they are both early twenties and just starting stressful careers. They are sexually active, but always use contraception. However, disaster strikes. The contraceptive fails, and Alice becomes pregnant. At this point, thanks to the pro-choice movement, she has a choice.
 One choice is to abort the foetus. She does so, continues to work and becomes more successful, and she and Bob have a planned child in a few years time. Because she and Bob waited until they were prepared, emotionally and financially, their child - call her Annie - lives a happy healthy life. Possibly she gains a sister at some point, as Alice has a higher-paid job to return to and the couple have built up savings before Annie was born, so a second child becomes financially viable.
 The other choice is to continue with the unwanted pregnancy. Alice has a child - call her Betty - but because Alice and Bob were not financially/emotionally prepared for a child, Betty lives a poorer life. Furthermore, partly because Betty's arrival forced Alice to take extended maternity leave so she returns to a poorly paid job and partly because Alice and Bob did not have prepared savings to deal with Betty, Alice and Bob are poorer in a few years time and cannot afford a second child. Annie is never born, nor her potential future sibling.
 
 The choice, then, is not a clear-cut issue between 'life' and 'death', even if you wish to consider a foetus as a living organism. Instead, the choice is between Annie and Betty - two possible routes, both of which are filled with life. The choice is not 'kill a child vs have a child' (as Archie sees it), it is 'have a child now vs have a child later'.
 
 Postscript: Regarding the alternative of 'adoption' - I have deliberately left this out of my considerations as an unrealistic option. There were 1.2 million abortions in the US last year, and ~127,000 children were adopted, of which 2/5 were from publicly funded operations (assuming last year was similar to 2001). Putting an extra million babies up for adoption each year is entirely unfeasible - parents would be turned away and would be expected to care for their own children. 
 Such an alternative also detracts from my main point - that the choice to abort a child 'now' can result in the existence of a separate child in the future, who otherwise would not have existed.
 
 Post-postscript: This post might be tinged with my mildly deterministic leanings. However, I don't see that as any reason to discard it.

 William J. Larsen, (New York: Churchill Livingstone, 1998), 1-17.
 
 "In this text, we begin our description of the developing human with the formation and differentiation of the male and female sex cells or gametes, which will unite at fertilization to initiate the embryonic development of a new individual. ... Fertilization takes place in the oviduct ... resulting in the formation of a zygote containing a single diploid nucleus. Embryonic development is considered to begin at this point... This moment of zygote formation may be taken as the beginning or zero time point of embryonic development."
 
 
 
 Human Embryology & Teratology
 Ronan R. O'Rahilly, Fabiola Muller, (New York: Wiley-Liss, 1996), 5-55.
 
 "Fertilization is an important landmark because, under ordinary circumstances, a new, genetically distinct human organism is thereby formed... Fertilization is the procession of events that begins when a spermatozoon makes contact with a secondary oocyte or its investments... The zygote ... is a unicellular embryo... "The ill-defined and inaccurate term pre-embryo, which includes the embryonic disc, is said either to end with the appearance of the primitive streak or ... to include neurulation. The term is not used in this book."
 
 Adding to the consensus of contemporary textbooks, is the testimony of older medical texts as well:
 
 * Human Embryology, 3rd ed.
 Bradley M. Patten, (New York: McGraw Hill, 1968), 43.
 
 "It is the penetration of the ovum by a spermatozoan and resultant mingling of the nuclear material each brings to the union that constitues the culmination of the process of fertilization and marks the initiation of the life of a new individual."
 
 * Biological Principles and Modern Practice of Obstetrics
 J.P. Greenhill and E.A. Friedman, (Philadelphia: W.B. Sanders, 1974), 17.
 
 "The zygote thus formed represents the beginning of a new life."
 
 * Pathology of the Fetus and the Infant, 3d ed.
 E.L. Potter and J.M. Craig, (Chicago: Year Book Medical Publishers, 1975), vii.
 
 "Every time a sperm cell and ovum unite a new being is created which is alive and will continue to live unless its death is brought about by some specific condition." 
 
 In addition to the consistent testimony found in medical textbooks, there is some equally conclusive evidence that exists on the public record. In 1981, a United States Senate judiciary subcommittee received the following testimony from a collection of medical experts (Subcommittee on Separation of Powers to Senate Judiciary Committee S-158, Report, 97th Congress, 1st Session, 1981):
 
 * Professor Micheline Matthews-Roth
 Harvard University Medical School
 
 "It is incorrect to say that biological data cannot be decisive...It is scientifically correct to say that an individual human life begins at conception."
 
 * Dr. Alfred M. Bongioanni
 Professor of Pediatrics and Obstetrics, University of Pennsylvania
 
 "I have learned from my earliest medical education that human life begins at the time of conception."
 
 * Dr. Jerome LeJeune
 Professor of Genetics, University of Descartes
 
 "After fertilization has taken place a new human being has come into being. [It] is no longer a matter of taste or opinion...it is plain experimental evidence. Each individual has a very neat beginning, at conception."
 
 * Professor Hymie Gordon
 Mayo Clinic
 
 "By all the criteria of modern molecular biology, life is present from the moment of conception."
 
 * Dr. Watson A. Bowes
 University of Colorado Medical School
 
 "The beginning of a single human life is from a biological point of view a simple and straightforward matter - the beginning is conception."
 
 The official Senate report reached this conclusion:
 
 Physicians, biologists, and other scientists agree that conception marks the beginning of the life of a human being - a being that is alive and is a member of the human species. There is overwhelming agreement on this point in countless medical, biological, and scientific writings.

 I have already presented my arguement in our recent discussions in other threads. Perhaps you have forgotten so I will present it again. **When there is more than one person involved, the state has the right to intervene.***
 
 To support this arguement from another angle that might be more difficult for you to ignore:
 
 From section IX B of the Roe vs Wade decision:
 
As we have intimated above, it is reasonable and appropriate for a State to decide that at some point in time another interest, that of health of the mother or that of potential human life, becomes significantly involved. The woman's privacy is no longer sole and any right of privacy she possesses must be measured accordingly. 
 
 
 Texas urges that, apart from the Fourteenth Amendment, life begins at conception and is present throughout pregnancy, and that, therefore, the State has a compelling interest in protecting that life from and after conception. We need not resolve the difficult question of when life begins. When those trained in the respective disciplines of medicine, philosophy, and theology are unable to arrive at any consensus, the judiciary, at this point in the development of man's knowledge, is not in a position to speculate as to the answer. 

 This is the conclusion of the Justices of the Supreme Court whose Roe vs Wade decision gave women back abortion rights - justices that I and nearly all pro-choice people would view as better judges than you of what the US government can and cannot do.
 
 Roe vs Wade left that determination of personhood open since there was no consensus between "those trained in the respective disciplines of medicine, philosophy, and theology". In arguing the issue of personhood here in this forum, we are attempting to do exactly that - reach a consensus. These comments by Roe vs Wade meant that, if a consensus could be reached, then the state could control abortion based on the idea of personhood.
 
 We know that we have not reached a consensus on personhood. That is why it is worth discussing it and why this point is quite relevant to the abortion debate.
 
 Either way, despite the fact that we have not reached a consensus, Roe vs Wade DOES still allow for state interference for other reasons - namely viability.
 
 From Roe vs Wade section X:
 
We repeat, however, that the State does have an important and legitimate interest in preserving and protecting the health of the pregnant woman, whether she be a resident of the State or a nonresident who seeks medical consultation and treatment there, and that it has still another important and legitimate interest in protecting the potentiality of human life. These interests are separate and distinct. Each grows in substantiality as the woman approaches term and, at a point during pregnancy, each becomes "compelling." 
 ...
 With respect to the State's important and legitimate interest in potential life, the "compelling" point is at viability. This is so because the fetus then presumably has the capability of meaningful life outside the mother's womb. State regulation protective of fetal life after viability thus has both logical and biological justifications. If the State is interested in protecting fetal life after viability, it may go so far as to proscribe abortion during that period, except when it is necessary to preserve the life or health of the mother. 

 
 So, the Justices of the Supreme Court (the ones that gave women the right to abortion) that decided Roe vs Wade view that personhood and viability are both compelling reasons for the state to intervene in abortion rights. Since personhood has not been well defined by society, that left viability as the main compelling reason by which they argued restrictions on abortion rights.
 
 You apparently think that your view of the state never intervening should automatically be true - despite the fact that 84% of Americans disagree with you and that the essentially pro-choice justices of the Supreme court that decided Roe vs Wade disagree with you. Perhaps you think that you are so incredibly important that your views should be automatically paramount - without you first needing to convince the rest of us. Nearly all of us would disagree.

The statement, "There are no objective moral truths", does not deny the existence of "objective truths". It denies objective "moral'" truths.

 Ok, let's probe a little further then.
 
 
Since the statement in itself is not a "moral" proposition claiming to be objectively true, it is not contradictory.

 Now, if a moral objectivist were to say (as he surely would), "murder is objectively immoral," he would be uttering a moral proposition. The moral relativist must, by virtue of his own premise, deny the truth of that proposition. He must say, "no, murder is not objectively immoral." But that reply is a moral proposition. Therefore, in order for it to actually counter the moral objectivist's proposition, the moral relativist's moral proposition must itself be objectively true. But that would present a contradiction between the relativist's initial premise, and the conclusion compelled by that premise.
 
 
According to your logic, if no one believed a thing to be immoral, it still could be so. Care to give an example?

 An analogy would be the fact that we live in a heliocentric universe. That fact was true even before it was discovered to be true. It was true even though the overwhelming opinion believed the opposite.
 
 That, of course, is an example of a physical truth. I see no compelling argument supporting the proposition that there is no such thing as objective metaphysical truth. Because moral relativism necessarily leads to logical contradictions, I think objective moral truth must exist. Unless we are willing to dispense with reason and logic, in which case we cannot fault either side of the abortion argument for being "unreasonable" or "illogical."

As far as I am concerned, you are missing a major part to your argument. That is: that an action/opinion is not always restricted to the moral/immoral, but instead can be amoral. Scientific fact is amoral - that the solar system is heliocentric is a perfect example of this.
 
 Thus, to contradict 'murder is objectively immoral', you can simply say 'murder is subjective, but I don't like it' - that is, 'there is no absolute standard by which to judge the morality of murder (but I find it immoral)'. This isn't a moral statement, unless you include a further axiom of 'belief in the correct morals is morally right' - in which case, we're in all sorts of headache territory. Instead, it is an objective (disputed) 'fact' - that I believe murder to be subjective.

 Even granting the category of "amoral" for the sake of argument, the conclusion is still the same. The claim "X is not objectively immoral," if assuming a category of amoral, is not the same as the claim "X is moral." So, I don't think that I overlooked the possibility of amoral actions at all in the two posts I referenced. 
 
 Take golf as an example. Suppose after 18 holes, Tiger Woods was tied with Phil Mickelson. Suppose further that a Tiger Woods fan proclaimed, "Tiger is beating Mickelson." The reply would be, "It is not true that Tiger is beating Mickelson" (this is what the simple reply "no, he is not" means). That would be a true statement whether Tiger was actually losing, or whether he was tied with Mickelson. Now, I try to apply this concept even more below.
 
 
Thus, to contradict 'murder is objectively immoral', you can simply say 'murder is subjective, but I don't like it' - that is, 'there is no absolute standard by which to judge the morality of murder (but I find it immoral)'. This isn't a moral statement, unless you include a further axiom of 'belief in the correct morals is morally right' - in which case, we're in all sorts of headache territory. Instead, it is an objective (disputed) 'fact' - that I believe murder to be subjective.

 I'm afraid this doesn't counter my argument. If it is true that there are no objective moral truths, then a moral relativist must logically deny the truth of any claim of moral objectivity. That is the only conclusion that can follow from the premise. So, if a moral objectivest says, "X is objectively immoral," the relativist logically must deny that as being a true statement. The relativist must say, "It is false that X is objectively immoral." Notice that that reply is not saying that X is moral. It is simply negating the objectivist's claim. But that negation is itself a moral claim which, to be effective, must be objectively true. But were it to be so, then the conclusion contradicts the premise.
 
 
My turn. Depending on what country you are brought up in, you are more likely to support/oppose the death penalty. How is there a 'moral absolute' governing this?

 I don't quite understand this question. If one were to grant that morality is objective, then it seems at least possible that administrating the death penalty could be either objectively moral or objectively immoral.
 
 
EDIT: As a second counter, it is perfectly possible to be subjective about subjectivity. Hence my favourite phrase - "there are no absolutes - and we're not even sure about that".
